content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												The best Splinter Cell game to date.  I'm a huge fan of stealth games.  Chaos Theory came out near the end of what I like to call the Golden Age of Stealth games and it still holds up today, for the most part.  Story wise the game is lacking, which is one of the reasons I would rank Choas Theory under games like Metal Gear Solid 3.  The graphics aren't great even for a game that came out in 2005.  Enemy AI is decent for the most part, but their imposibly quick reaction time to spotting you can be frustrating.  Somtimes if you bump into an enemy or are somehow spotted they will immediately start firing, as in no animation of them turning around or rasing their gun, just immediatly firing.  Apart from that the AI is decent. Mechanincally it's a phenomenal stealth game worthy of the genere.  There are light and sound indicators telling you how visibil you are or how much noise your making, it even tells you the noice level at which the enemy will hear you.  Unlike recent releases in the franchise, Chaos Theory isn't a game you can approach with guns blazing.  You actually have to use stealth.  You can't fire from the hip and you have to pull your gun out every time you want to fire which decreases your movement speed significantly.  The PC version runs fine on modern systems, I had very few problems, and the game supports 1920x1080 without having to mod the game(old titles tend to be hit or miss with resolution support).  If you have a high refresh rate monitor like I do you should know that the game is locked at 100 FPS.  Keyboard and Mouse work fine, but it doesn't have controller support like most title now do, so you'll have to figit with it if you want to use a controller.Story Score: 6/10Rest of the Game Score: 9/10

												For a game that is, at the time of writing this review, almost 12 years old, it still holds up today as a visual and gameplay masterpiece from a once great developer called Ubisoft.The third installment of the franchise improved on its predecesors in countless ways. Its light,shadow and sound mechanics are unmatched to this day.The game comes from a time where developers actually cared somewhat for the PC market, which can be most visibly seen in the movement speed variation of Sam Fisher, that could be controlled by the scroll wheel. A feature that for some inexplicable reason noone has tried to emulate.Visuals that hold up even today, stealth that is simultaneously unforgiving and fun, varied missions locations and enemies make the experience of playing Chaos Theory one of a kind. And that's all without mentioning the performance of Michael Ironside as Sam Fisher.Not recommending this game to everyone because most people today are morons who wouldn't know how to play this game today since it doesn't have a built in wallhack, invasive HUD or achievements you can masturbate to.Now give me my ♥♥♥♥ing badge.

Posted: March 17, 2014
												As a guy who's played Conviction first, I have to say I'm actually having more fun playing this game more. While I still feel like the controls could've been better, something I also feel about Double Agent, I enjoy the game immensely. The most obvious reason for the game is the story, which isn't "US vs. Russia". From what I can gather, it's North Korea.Chaos Theory is also easily the best game in the series, according to the dozens of reviews by new fans and Splinter Cell veterans alike. I certainly would agree; stealth is paramount in any situation. Sam's suit comes with a variety of items to help you know when you're hidden, or when you've screwed the pooch. Light sensors to let you know when you're visible, sound detectors to let you know how slow you need to move to keep quiet. An option I'm familiar with because of Double Agent is the OPSAT, which is a real-time objectives and map menu, meaning you'll need to hide to use it effectively. Hacking is way more interesting than Double Agent, and shooting, when done right, feels like an accomplishment.Graphics wise, character models in game show visible age and are acceptable if you remember it's from 2005. Environments though show great lighting and attention to detail. I did get a feeling of being in the locations Sam visited. And again, for a game in 2005, it looks just as good as some games from this decade.Sound is phenomanal, with a soundtrack by Amon Tobin and layered for different events in gameplay so it never feels stale. Sam Fisher is voiced by Michael Ironside; not the new guy who everyone hates for some ridiculous reason. Seriously guys, move on. In fact the voice acting and the script writing are good too; minus the enemy/foreign character voices. While Sam and his pals are witty and relatable, enemies tend to have such bad and stereotyped accents. And let's not forget the character "Long Dan". Turning on native voices solves this, but there's no subtitle option to let you know what's being said, so it's more for immersion after beating the game.So yes, I'm joining the bandwagon. But at least it's a good one; Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory is easily one of the best stealth games I've played. And it's one that really deserves it.

Posted: February 24, 2014
												Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory is an amazing game and instantly worth a recommend if you are a fan of the stealth genre or just like the series and haven't gotten into the 3rd instalment for some reason. It's worthy of its Steam-tag "Best in the series". I have debated with myself about it, but I would add this game to one of my favourite games of all-time. No, I am not a huge stealth enthusiast. Also being a legacy title, it doesn't have any UPlay integration at all!A good stealth game is dependant on solid mechanics and unlike later instalments of Splinter Cell. Chaos Theory and its predecessors are mostly stealth driven games.  Sam Fisher is given 3 settings in his trademark 3-scope goggles (Night-Vision, Heat-Vision and an EEV mode which highlights electronic equipment),  an EMP function on his handgun and of course a knife.  The game also features  sound and light bars in the HUD to show how silent and hidden you are which is a nice touch. With these tools, some environmental manipulation and the solid controls it's possible to get through entire missions without being detected or firing a bullet. Infact in the 1st mission I got through with only firing 2 on normal difficulty.Controls are excellent here on the PC with a keyboard & mouse. With the controls already premapped sensibly and are all rebindable.  A notable control mechanic is how you can alter Fisher's walking/sneaking speed via the scroll wheel of the mouse which is a really nice touch. The game does have a good tutorial which teaches you how to work with these efficiently.The plot is worthy of the Tom Clancy name and is immensely detailed. I didn't understand it as a child in 2005 and I still only have a relative understanding of it now with some help from the Wiki and knowledge from previous playthroughs. It follows on from the previous 2 installments and takes you all around the world. That's the idea of the plot without mentioning spoilers.Visuals are from the Unreal Engine 2.5 and are pretty solid. The game is from 2005, so it's safe to say that the visuals are antiquated. The lighting plays a key role in the game as it can be the difference between having bullets hurled at Fisher. The textures are antiquated for the most part, but that's to be expected. Still it doesn't look too bad for a 2005 game.Soundtrack was composed by both Amon Tobin and the well-know Jesper Kyd. The OST is amazing and each tune has a unique vibe that sets the scene whether it be ambient whilst Sam Fisher is sneaking around or frantic when enemies are firing at you due to your carelessness. It was also apparently featured on the UK motoring TV show Top Gear which says quite a bit and my favourite tracks from El Cargo (the 2nd mission) have been part of my personal music library for quite some time.So all in all give it a try. At its current price of £9.99 ($9.99/9.99€), it's not a bad deal for stealth enthusasts. Though it has been reduced by Ubisoft to at least 75% making it cost around £2.50, I would it's worth getting for most gamers.That's all I can say about the game. If you want to know more there are a myriad of reviews out there. One which I think sums it up well is MrSnuggleDuck's review here: 


YouTube™ Video: Splinter Cell Chaos Theory Review 

			Views: 19,353		

			Sam Fisher returns for a third Splinter Cell game. Terrorists have turned to cyber warfare as their weapon of choice and Fisher must uncover the source before World War Three begins.

												The last TRUE Splinter Cell Game. If you love stealth games, this is a must have.Iv'e been a Splinter Cell fan since the original. The first two games were great, but Choas Theory is a masterpiece. Ubisoft seemed to forget what Splinter Cell was about with EVERY game after this. Dumping stealth for generic action. Posted: October 9, 2015
												Splinter Cell - Chaos Theory is stealth genre gold. It's the third title of the Splinter Cell franchise and is simply the best stealth game of the series. Ubisoft Montreal did great work on this. The character, Sam Fisher, is a veteraned soldier of the United States working in secret for the government's NSA. The game provides well written and voiced dialogues for Sam and most of the characters in the game that can be quite humorous at points.  The core stealth mechanics of the game are extremely well done and fun to play once learned. The actions and controls of the gameplay are pratical and fluid. The shadow and lighting systems are easy to use and provide clear feedback to the player at all times. The takedown system is fun to use and capturing an enemy is challenging at times. The stealth gadgets and weapons are fun to use and have some creative examples like sticky cameras, shock bullets, pistol emp, and more.Level design is extremely creative and the game contains some very cool setpieces and level design.The environmental sound is an aspect of gameplay as well. Game sounds can be heard by your opponents and even microphone talk in Coop can be heard by guards. Guards are well voiced and some have some creative writing that can be pretty entertaining at times. Gunfire sounds fine. Most of your weapons are silenced but it makes sense. Environmental sound effects are great. The music is done by Amon Tobin, a braziallian electronic music artist, and it fits perfect with the stealth mood of the genre. Its a fantastic soundtrack for a gameGraphics are quite nice on this game. Especially when set to higher values. But for most of the game they'll be viewed through your night vison goggles. Graphics look great on most systems and are not demanding. This is the best game of the series and is really a stealth classic.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												Recently purchased this again. Was one of my favourite games when it came out, not just in the stealth genre, but in general, it made the idea of sneaking around, and also not killing, fun.I cannot speak for multiplayer or coop, so please think of this as only a single player review.Story isn't the strongest point, but is still pretty good, nothing fancy. The gameplay is where the game shines. Intuitive controls and a good hud system to allow players to exploit their environment to the fullest, with a good balance of choices which allow the player to feel in control of Sam, despite linear and clear missions. You decide if you want to sneak, when to distract, what tools to use, from which direction to leap upon guards etc. I feel it's hard to put into words how the game manages to pull off beautifully many things, aiming for Sam to be a stealthy ninja, a predator, a covert operative with many tricks, moves and gadgets up his sleeve, which add up to a fun balance of power, not making the player feel too powerful (the difficulty isn't hard for this game, which isn't too offputting) but not too weak. AI has a variety of tricks, though it isn't anything mindblowing, it is still enough to remind the player that you better anticipate some pushback from the npcs.I think the campaign was short, I haven't played it through yet (again), but the length and replayability is still decent.Graphics are still highly enjoyable for an older game and has solid frames per second with highest settings. A proper mix of dynamic shadows, decent shaders and textures, solid animations and physics, allowed me to still immerse myself into the game without being distracted by too much unrealism. Doesn't mean you should expect the quality of modern games, but this game does enough, in my opinion, to still be eyecandy, the basic solid kind of candy, like milk chocolate.Happily reinstalling this game on my mediocre laptop, I didn't find many problems, which I were slightly expecting, due to so many, not merely old games, but newer ones also having so many problems (which can nevertheless be fixed in many cases). The major problem is that shader model 3 doesn't work for me, the screen goes white, but upon investigation I think it has more to do with the intel HD graphics card than the game, or my drivers anyway (SM2 is still good and looks good). My laptop is a win7, intel dual core 2gHz, 4gRAM with shared graphics card memory, dedicated only 64mb. So it might just work for the majority. I should add that I always add the admin rights and compatibility mode XPSP3 by habit, so that might also have had something to do with it.People who are not even fans of stealth games might find SCCT a luring gateway drug into the world of patient stalking and picking your own time when to pick npcs off one by one with satisfaction.

												One of my favorite games to play. Perfect gameplay. Graphics could be upgraded a little but by sides that its a great game.

Posted: September 26, 2014
												One of the greatest stealth games ever created. It's in the Holy Trinity of stealth games, along with Thief 2 and Hitman Blood Money.Gameplay: There's a light and dark stealth system, which means that staying in the dark is crucial to sneaking by. Some of the tensest moments are spent hiding in the dark while a guy with a huge gun is so close you can see his nosehairs. You can always see how visible you are and how much noise you are making in the HUD, which provides a lot of convienence. You can also use sounds in the enviorment to mask sounds you are making, like thunder. I recall one moment where you have to open a loud door in front of a sleeping guard, and if you don't open it while he's snoring, he'll wake up. You can also interrogate guards you've grabbed, and it leads to a lot of hilarious and memorable moments. The gadgets from Pandora Tomorrow make a return (the previous game in the series) while adding some new additions to Fisher's arsenal. The gameplay overall is tense and satisfying, and makes you feel like a badass spy.Graphics: The lighting system is brilliant, and looks better than most modern games. The character models, however, are lack luster. I remember one specific guard who's gums were light green. And Sam himself, when he's not wearing mask, has a consistent cross-eyed dumb look on his face. The textures are fine, not really anything special. It looks fine, overall.Sound: When the absolutely kickass music isn't playing, there's atmospheric sounds and really sets the mood. The sound design of effects like footsteps rivals even the Thief games. The enemies have very stereotypical accents, and it's done for laughs. The music starting to play when an enemy is suspicous and is looking for you really kicks up the tension.The sound design overall, is fantastic.Level Design: There's usually at least one alternate way to get into an area (although it heavily relies on pipes and crawl spaces.) It's non-linear and sprawling (excluding the first level) and is fun to explore. The level design is great (while not anywhere near the masterful level design of the Thief games.)Conclusion: Buy this game. If you're looking to get into stealth games, this is the game. One of the greatest games I've ever played.And I don't know why the enemies can't see the 3 suns on top of Fisher's head, shut up.

												One of my favorite stealth games. I first played this back on ps2. Man there was such a graphics boost once i got to pc.

Posted: November 25, 2015
												Best stealth-espionage game ever created by mandkind...Also the best Splinter Cell game there isDefinetly buy it

Posted: May 27, 2014
												The epitome of the entire Splinter Cell franchise, Chaos Theory marks the high-point of the stealth genre(except maybe losing out to Thief in that regard). Unlike most games involving guns, the most important skill in Splinter Cell is situational awareness, as opposed to the usual reflex-aiming; this is because Sam Fisher is a man, not a stormtrooper strung out on stimulants. Multiple methods of entry and escape from a room or area are usually avaliable, but many of these paths are guarded by some form of deterrant. Cameras are usually hidden in shadow or difficult to see areas, and guards can (and do) change routes. All of these things means that the game tends to promote a cautious advance rather than a blitz. Not a good experience if bloodlust is prevalant.TL;DR the game rewards you for being cautious, aware, and using your brain to take the path less traveled by.

Posted: March 25
												(one) Game in the Original Splinter Cell lineup; namely, the: 3rd part of iterations in the espionage franchise series.Game with the best flushed out engine up to then and thus (best) gaming experience of the first trilogy -series of games, if not at least in ways of the gameplay.Sound; music, atmosphere, acting / Design, aesthetics; the lighting. --All equally amazing ergo movingly engaging... the 'Sights' & 'Sounds'.Everything about this game is quality IMO, minus the shooting mechanics which could be better but are probably such for a reason in that it is a 'stealth-game'.And a true one at that.Amazing Game. This is probably one of the best (modern) stealth games available on the PC. (available on other platforms as well, and one of my favorites)

Posted: January 8
												An abysmal port of one of the best stealth games ever made. I'd recommend the game, but the port is terrible. 55 minutes is the longest I've gone without a crash, it has no overlay support at all so if you want to publish screenshots, you have to work some tech magic and do things the long way. If you ever need to alt tab, you can pretty much guarantee that the game will crash when you try to open it again and you'll have to set your graphics settings up all over again, so if you hear a notification in the background or whatever, you really are better off just saving and closing the game properly.The game it's self runs fine and there's no issues gameplay wise, it's just the crashes that nearly always happen after a cutscene or when you start a new level. Sometimes the game will mess up right from the moment you click play and will either run in a weird sized window that you can't open properly or just be a black screen with sound.

Posted: August 11, 2015
												If anyone cares to read my reviews and are wondering what the best of the best in the Splinter Cell is series than this is it.  Everything from the first two games done to perfection.  Pure stealth that you expect from this series toppled with better controls and interface.  This is where they struck gold.  Its a shame they started dumbing down the series after this.  Stealth began to take a backseat for edgy dark broodiness and action!  If you like stealth in any way and haven't played this one than you're doing yourself a great disservice.  NO game touches this in just how everything fits perfectly.  Better use of shadows.  The ability to draw enemies to you by whistling and distracting them with lights.  Not to mention the mini emp device in the pistol that lets you short circuit lights or other electricity in case shooting is too loud.  They really thought of everything with this game.  And then the PC version of Double Agent comes next and I've already talked about that one *shudders*.  Going from this to that is just mind baffling!

Posted: October 19, 2016
												Spy game from 2005.+Looks fantastic for its time+Spy equipment+Tense sneaking and satisfaction for tricking the guards succesfully+Some great levels (gargo ship and bank robbery are my favorites)+Fun mini games like hacking and lockpicking+Whistle+Less linear than the previous game (it's still very linear game)+THOSE 2 RADIO SONGS ♥♥♥♥ING ROCK!!!+Voice acting (good guys (espesially Sam Fisher))-Voice acting (bad guys)±AI is pretty clunky: sometimes it's utterly passive and stupid, sometimes it spots you from a mile away or just keeps camping the same area. Most of the it gets its job done.-Annoying music-Some bad missions (the first no casualties-mission was pretty awful)-Some dumbed down stuff: when the NPCs are searching for you, they walk the slowest pace possible as if they were scared (in PT they were a lot faster so you didn't want to draw any attention), pistol is dumbed down so shooting light bulbs takes now more luck than skill, no more door roll, also hiding in shadows is now easier than before imo.-Not as interesting missions as the train level from PT.-Story is not worth following-Don't play this game if you get headache easily, the nightvision goggles will♥♥♥♥♥♥your eyes.In conclusion it's a very enjoyable stealth game which makes you feel like a ninja as you master the mechanics and equipment. I'd suggest you to play with the hardest mode if you have any experience from the previous games, and also because the AI glitches less that way imo. I couldn't review the multiplayer mode because it's basically dead.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
The best Splinter Cell title ever madeSo, Blacklist turned out to be pretty good and a huge improvement over Conviction which was a detraction from the core SC formula. However, the definitive SC experience will always be Chaos Theory, which largely corrected the flaws of the previous games while further improving the strengths.When this game released in 2005, it was a graphical masterpiece that pushed the consoles to their limits, and also put strain on the most powerful PC GPUs of the time. Ten years later, the graphics still hold up pretty well, especially the lighting effects which are essential to the stealth gameplay. The freedom of choice you get in this game is incredible, and sadly absent in the later titles. In previous games, it was difficult to do things more than one way. That guard HAD to be KOed/killed. That door's lock HAD to be picked. There was rarely more than one path. In Chaos Theory, the levels are more sandbox-like, with multiple possible routes for you to discover. You can break locks or you can spend time picking them.. You can wait for a guard to come walking up to a door, and then slam it into his face with all your strength, or you can wait for him to turn away, and do a standard stealth KO. You can open a door slowly, pushing it a little more forward with each press of the W key, or you can fling it open and exposing yourself. You can hack electronic locks or retinal scanners or you can force guards to cooperate. You can hack PCs to disable lasers and cameras or you can play a dodging minigame. It's also much easier to carve your own 100% avoidance path this time because you get a lot of room to breathe.Every single enemy could be interrogated which expanded gameplay possibilities and also made for amusing easter eggs. The alarm system was much more forgiving without making the game too easy. Gone are the days of instant-failure because some dude saw you even if he didn't get a chance to radio for backup. The story was quite engaging, and made Sam Fisher more involved in the plot rather than just an everyday cleanup guy.AI was significantly improved from older games. Enemies would start using flashlights, lighting flares, and calling backup instead of just walking blindly towards the sight of a broken light.Melee attacks, a serious letdown in the past, are now my favourite way to deal with trouble. Sam Fisher now gets a knife that can do one-hit kills. If he wants to go non-lethal, he throws a fast punch to the head - a LOT more effective and realistic than the stupid elbow move in the previous games. Chaos Theory isn't a shooter, and it's difficult to play it like one without dying within seconds. Nevertheless, should the♥♥♥♥♥♥hit the fan, the guns are more effective than before, giving you choices of attachments (gadget launcher or shotgun or sniper attachment?) and making ammo more readily available (you can now carry more than 2 mags per gun at a time). The pistol is more accurate so you don't waste so many rounds to take out one light. The rifle with its attachments can make for many interesting possibilities (long range stealth kills, sticky shocker KOs, etc). Co-op mode was the first of its kind, allowing two players to play as Splinter Cells and boost each other over walls and work in tandem to do coordinated kills. It was even more fun than the campaign, but sadly a bit short.I've never tried Spies vs Mercenaries so no comment there.Anyone who enjoys stealth games like Metal Gear Solid and Hitman will find this well worth a few bucks.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Chaos Theory is the 3rd in the critically acclaimed Splinter Cell series which is based on Tom Clancy's series of novels with the similar name. This is an 8 year old game that actually aged quite well: some of the levels look quite good and the game utilises the lighting and shadow effects superbly.You play as Sam Fisher, member of a secret US black ops team, and are dispatched to various locations in order to find evidence, defuse a bomb, eliminate a terrorist, capture someone alive, etc. Although the game is linear, throughout the missions you are given secondary and opportunity objectives, therefore, the game tries to lengthen the singleplayer experience as much as possible. At the end of each level you are given a rating in accordance with the number of objectives you completed. In addition to this, the game counts whether or not you killed someone - this, in fact, lowers your score so it's best to focus on the stealth approach, otherwise achieving 100% is impossible. While making sure you are not seen by anybody or any cameras you can also knock your enemies out and hide the bodies.I like how varied the environment is: Sam can use a lot of objects, can climb a lot of things and can hang from a lot of places. There are also minigames in each level: you can do a lot of lockpicking, hacking and before knocking out or killing someone it's worth interrogating them to get some more intel for your objective. These interrogations can be funny due to the well-written script.It is unfortunate that coop and multiplayer are not played anymore, so, if this is on sale, make sure you grab it but only for the singleplayer experience.

The best Splinter Cell title ever madeSo, Blacklist turned out to be pretty good and a huge improvement over Conviction which was a detraction from the core SC formula. However, the definitive SC experience will always be Chaos Theory, which largely corrected the flaws of the previous games while further improving the strengths.When this game released in 2005, it was a graphical masterpiece that pushed the consoles to their limits, and also put strain on the most powerful PC GPUs of the time. Ten years later, the graphics still hold up pretty well, especially the lighting effects which are essential to the stealth gameplay. The freedom of choice you get in this game is incredible, and sadly absent in the later titles. In previous games, it was difficult to do things more than one way. That guard HAD to be KOed/killed. That door's lock HAD to be picked. There was rarely more than one path. In Chaos Theory, the levels are more sandbox-like, with multiple possible routes for you to discover. You can break locks or you can spend time picking them.. You can wait for a guard to come walking up to a door, and then slam it into his face with all your strength, or you can wait for him to turn away, and do a standard stealth KO. You can open a door slowly, pushing it a little more forward with each press of the W key, or you can fling it open and exposing yourself. You can hack electronic locks or retinal scanners or you can force guards to cooperate. You can hack PCs to disable lasers and cameras or you can play a dodging minigame. It's also much easier to carve your own 100% avoidance path this time because you get a lot of room to breathe.Every single enemy could be interrogated which expanded gameplay possibilities and also made for amusing easter eggs. The alarm system was much more forgiving without making the game too easy. Gone are the days of instant-failure because some dude saw you even if he didn't get a chance to radio for backup. The story was quite engaging, and made Sam Fisher more involved in the plot rather than just an everyday cleanup guy.AI was significantly improved from older games. Enemies would start using flashlights, lighting flares, and calling backup instead of just walking blindly towards the sight of a broken light.Melee attacks, a serious letdown in the past, are now my favourite way to deal with trouble. Sam Fisher now gets a knife that can do one-hit kills. If he wants to go non-lethal, he throws a fast punch to the head - a LOT more effective and realistic than the stupid elbow move in the previous games. Chaos Theory isn't a shooter, and it's difficult to play it like one without dying within seconds. Nevertheless, should the♥♥♥♥♥♥hit the fan, the guns are more effective than before, giving you choices of attachments (gadget launcher or shotgun or sniper attachment?) and making ammo more readily available (you can now carry more than 2 mags per gun at a time). The pistol is more accurate so you don't waste so many rounds to take out one light. The rifle with its attachments can make for many interesting possibilities (long range stealth kills, sticky shocker KOs, etc). Co-op mode was the first of its kind, allowing two players to play as Splinter Cells and boost each other over walls and work in tandem to do coordinated kills. It was even more fun than the campaign, but sadly a bit short.I've never tried Spies vs Mercenaries so no comment there.Anyone who enjoys stealth games like Metal Gear Solid and Hitman will find this well worth a few bucks.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												(Played in 2014, without rose tinted glasses for old games)A decent game from 2005 that stands up well to what is released today, but I would rate it "average". It looks like DeusEx:HumanRevolution imitated much of this game, so if you liked that, you'll like this. Gameplay is solid and tactical, but I found it a bit too linear and scripted. The controls also feel a bit clunky, especially if you have to start shooting. I had a few minor issues with light detection. Most graphics are average (it was designed for first gen xbox), but some details were really good, like a floor cleaner really making the part he cleans with his mop more reflective as he goes! Maybe worth getting in a steam sale. Fortunately no Uplay account required.Essential PC tip: go to pcgamingwiki for instructions on how to increase the FieldOfView, which is too low.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												Again it's very late to write the review of this game - as it was release for quite a long back.Still, I am compelled to write the same cause of the game itself. As usual I will be dividing my review in parts. So without any further adieu lets jump into the business here - Story: The plot is, as with any other "Splinter Cell" title, is self-untangling. At the beginning player will have a very limited knowledge about the entire plot and that is revealed as the game is progressed. The plot itself may not appeal to the average FPS people, who are looking for Aim-n-Shoot kinda play through. But if you invest enough time and senses into the game - the plot is very apt and con-sized.Gameplay: The best part of any "Splinter Cell" title. Yes, though its not an open world environment, still there are more than 1 ways to complete most of the missions. The player will be given ample scope and time and equipments to complete each of the missions as the way they see fit. Players can vary their tactics - they can go complete "Stealth" and not raise a SINGLE!! alarm to complete mission or they can take a bit more direct approach to solve mattes - using bullets, that is.The tools are great and fun to use as well - be it a sticky camera or optical fiber or Lock Pic they can make the players life a lot less painful.Graphics: Now, when we talk about in game graphics - we usually bring out some of the big names of the business but very easily forget about "Splinter Cell" titles. Even for an old game like Chaos Theory, trust me, the graphics is great. The shadows and the ambient glow from the street/table/wall lamps are just too good. But the best part of all of them are the different vision mode of Sam Fisher's goggles. To me, the "Night Vision" is one of the best rendered "night mode" across all the game titles.AI: The AI is a strong point in this game - specially how they react to a whisper or when they see a body. Some of the guards are as ignorant as ever yet some of they are very suspicious (even of their own breathing). AI bots take some predefined paths or some random one - specially after they are being alerted. Even an open door or torn curtain can raise there suspicion. Be very careful to watch your light and ambient noise meter all the time - and don't hesitate to grab one if needed.All in all I am really enjoying the game and I would surely recommend anyone who is looking a different breed of the FPS genre.- Go Covert -

												This game is a MUST OWN if you want a really well done hardcore stealth action game. It's difficult but you'll keep coming back for more. The game also has a neat coop mode, and proper multiplayer, however the internet servers had shut down long long ago...good thing THIS GAME HAS LAN!!!The game looks great even today, and controls well along with gamepad/controller support and widescreen support built-in, however the multiplayer and coop modes are capped at 30fps because the network packets sync at 30 and raising it would break the networking. Fun still though!(Don't be fooled by a small playtime. I've owned it on both PS2, and Xbox, and loved every bit of it.)

content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												I have just finished the 3rd mission in this game. I played TCSC Blacklist earlier this year and enjoyed that game, so based on the reviews I bought this one. I have to say that I am enjoying this 2005 game even more than the 2013 one! I guess that its because I like stealth games and Chaos Theory is certainly a stealth game done well. My only criticism is that it is mostly, but not completely linear, since there is clearly an 'ideal' path to take to complete each mission and in some places only one possible path. But importantly the game does not rush the player - a key factor of stealth games. I remain amazed that a game which is over 10 years old can give me so much enjoyment.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												One of the top 3 Stealth games of all time, right under Hitman Blood Money and Metal Gear Solid 3. Multiple ways to complete objectives yet the game forces you to go stealth. This game is unforgiving and that's what makes it great. There is never a point in time where it holds your hand. There are no objective markers, forcing you to interogate guards and eavesdrop on conversations to find infomation to lead you to your next location, all while remaining completely undetected. Your gadgets will help you stay out of the dark and stay out of sight. Brillant stealth game, highly recommend for players interested in the genre. Graphics have aged well for a 7 year old game too.

His character and skills are on FULL display here. -Take on your dangerous missions in many ways - never touch an enemy OR bring your assault shotgun attachement and party-Tactical whistling - simple and futurisic tools are at your disposal -Very robust mechanics, reliable and challenging AI (that scales well with difficulty levels) -Good graphics that even works at excelent frame rate on my 2003 Dell lapop/fax machine-No DRM -Recommendation: Easy mode: Quick save whenever you want. Fun mode: Whole mission without saves (unbind quicksave controls and iron man mode it!)-Graphics are not 2015 Triple-A level, do some research to decide-Hard to follow storyBe the ghost's shadow that saves the world

Posted: May 30, 2016
												I haven't written a review in a long time; since I was a dumb little kid that didn't really know. I first played this game when I was a kid and never realized how amazing this gem of a game truly was until I replayed it on steam and did both single and co-op modes (I have a twin, and he was doing his side of the work on this game as well) and h-h-huh-huhHOLY♥♥♥♥♥♥THIS GAME IS AND WILL FOREVER BE A TIMELESS CLASSIC.The gameplay is at it's peak in the series, in my opinion of course. It really had the classic Splinter Cell gameplay and had really started to emphasize on assault tactics if you preferred, which is pretty neat. I myself am a stealth guy, and I was not disappointed in the slightest bit when it came to seeking a challenge. Expert Stealth is probably THE way to play this game, as you will get the entire Splinter Cell experience. I was a kid when I played this originally so of course I was running in and spraying, bashing doors into the enemy LMAOOO sometimes your parnter! Even the soundtrack to this game is really good. Really ♥♥♥♥ing good as a matter of fact. Hats off to you, Amon Tobin! The soundtrack chilled and stressed out with you as the player depending on your situation in the game, and at the time of this release, I'm sure it must have been groundbreaking in terms of video games and OST. The sound and lighting aspects were on point, AI, gameplay, blah blah blah. It was all diamonds and gold for me man. This game really holds a valuable spot in my heart (as do many games, for I am beyond the deepest universal levels of all things geek and game) and I would give this a 12/10 because the soundtrack (Kokubo Sosho Battle theme is life) will forever be reminding me of when I used to sneak out haha. what is this water coming out of my eyes right now

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												So here is my review of "Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory".(just imagine and low voiced guy saying Tom Clancy)TL;DR it's in my top 10 stealth games, get it.So I'm going to split my review up into 4 sections, gameplay, story, graphics, & how does it compare to the newer games(?).GAMEPLAYTom Clancy's splinter cell CT has problems but also does things that I adore.Ok, stealth; the stealth in this game is realistic but it gets kinda annoying after a while.You see, there are 2 monitors attached to your U.I called your "aural monitor" and your "brightness monitor". Now of course your brightness has a big impact on you and your enemies. The bar works like a brightness setting I guess. Point is, the closer you get to light, the farther left (right?) it goes. If you are in full brightness then enemies I believe from anywhere can see you. Now the Aural monitor is the annoying part. The aural monitor watches your speed setting, the faster you go the easier enemies can hear you. Now the scoll wheel on your mouse functions as a speed changer, the closer you get to enemies the lower you scroll your mouse because unlike most of the games, you can't just walk behind a enemy and grab them, you have to gradually get slower until it prompts you to grab them, but this can f**k you over cause it doesn't tell you very much about the monitor. But I must admit, for it's problems I can forgive it, I...LOVE REALISM IN STEALTH GAMES! I am not a big fan of the cartoony stealth like "stealth ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s" or...well you get me. I like realistic stealth games where you are in situations that can mimic real life. This game does that almost perfectly, I guess this game i- I am getting off track. Stealth = 8/10STORYNow the story takes you through a bunch of locations ranging from a  Hokkaido Island (a dojo) to a giant ship( Maria Narcissa) and even Seoul, but no one likes the Seoul mission...The story is quite enjoyable if a bit cliche'ed but it does take you to some nice locations. story = 6/10.HOW DOES IT COMPARE TO NEWER SPINTER CELLSI've always found the new spinter cell odd, they changed so much. I felt and think they changed devs or engines, probably both. But I've always thought of conviction and blacklist as different games. They are great themselves it's just if you WANT a STEALTH game then choose this game. The newer ones are more likes AC, if you have someone in your way you kill them, but if you want a "stealth" game then you go for the ones that make you think about your decisions. If I kill this guy will anyone see it? Will I be able to move the body in time? Will anyone hear him drop? Those are the type of stealth games that in my opinion, represent the stealth genre greatly. How does the game fair? 8/10FINAL THOUGHTTom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory is a great stealth game. If you are a die-hard fan of stealth then you should have this game. Yes the FMV is cheesy but this is a game that was made in 2006, I don't blame it, and you shouldn't either. But for my final thought, this game is a underrated gem of the series, I find it a guilty pleasure, and from the reviews I see this is a very loved game. Pick it up, please, if you don't like it then just refund it.Tom Clancy's Splinter cell: Chaos Theory (I am saying Tom Clancy too much) get's my final rating of 8/10, a great game! If you enjoyed this review then leave a comment on my profile saying "+rep decent reviewer" it will make me happy <3

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												(After fiddling with the poor controls) Chaos Theory still holds up 11-ish years after release. Though I consider Conviction and Blacklist to be rock solid games, Chaos Theory is purebred stealth. The sound design/soundtrack is excellent, the graphics were incredible for the time (and are fine to look at today), and the dialogue between Fisher and his handlers is witty and entertaining. This is my favorite Splinter Cell and an all around must play for stealth fans. I personally have a hard time going back to older games and even though I played Conviction and Blacklist before this one, I can still find it amazing. If that doesn't speak for the quality, I don't know what else will.It's very cheap now and can be picked up for dirt cheap in sales. As far as my experience has gone, it has no issues on modern rigs. The biggest downside is that it ran on Gamespy, so the multiplayer and co-op functionality is gone.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												This is a great stealth game. It's basically more of the first games, with less bugs and a sound detection bar. It's just weird that there's an "Assault" option for loadouts, as going in guns blazing will ruin the game completely. The most enjoyable way to play it is by trying to stay unseen and taking out only the guys standing directly in your way to the objective (IMHO). Changing your speed with the scrollwheel is a neat mechanic that I liked about this game. So is the alt-fire on the pistol that disabled electronics (so that you don't have to shoot them anymore).It has a great soundtrack that changes every level and as you get spotted or identified.Oh, there's plot too, mainly so that the missions don't all appear the same.This brings me to the less enjoyable part of the game: the repetition. Pretty much all you do is sneak around people or lure them till you can get behind them and snatch them. This made it very hard to play the game for longer than an hour at once, and I became pretty bored of it nearing the end. Some more ways of getting the information you need or getting people out of your way would be cool. The airfoil rounds, sticky shockers and gas grenades are supposed to do that job, but they all work in pretty much the same way. I guess this game could just use a little less linear gameplay is what I'm getting at.This game is definitely worth your time though, even ten years after release.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2012
												The best video game I have ever played hands down. I have played through this countless times. It's perfect in every way and form. The solo campaign is lengthy with plenty of variety in environments. You'll sneak around cargo ships, apartmetns in NYC, and Japanese villages as the ultimate spy. Chaos Theory offers vast amounts of options for every level ensuring plenty of replay value. The graphics, while obviously old, still hold up pretty well to todays standards; with reflective surfaces, lots of realistic textures, and an AI system that is so much fun to mess with. The music, written by Amon Tobin, is fantastic and some of the best original soundtrack work for a video game I've heard. This is a game that you just NEED TO PLAY!The coop mode was amazing when it was working. It was at least 6 more missions that you could play with a friend and there were even some unique abilities you could do with your partner, like throwing him/her across hallways to knock out guards, or climbing them like a human ladder to get into higher windows. The servers aren't available anymore as far as I know, but I'm sure if you try and host one with your friend you should still be able to play it. The versus mode is a totally seperate game that's very creative and loads of fun. However! Be warned, this game is highly competitive and the players that are still playing online know the maps inside and out. It's best to play this mode with your friends until you get good enough to play against the 6 or so players that are still playing this online. Also, since the game's versus mode runs on an old engine, the lighting doesn't work anymore with new Nvidia video cards. There Is a fix if you go into the steam communtiy hub to fix it, but if you don't do this, the mercenaries flashlights won't work; which is not good considering you need the flashlight to see in the dark to find spies. Anyway, this game is a must play for anyone who's ever even had the slightest interest in video games... and considering you're reading this on "Steam", I'm almost positive you have some interest in video games yourself. So buy this game.. now.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												This was a awesome game back on my Playstation 2, and would hold up better today if it were not for the newer Splinter Cell Conviction (2010) and Splinter Cell Blacklist (2013), both vastly superior in every possible way. Having said that, Chaos Theory is still a fun game with pretty decent controls for a game that is so old. At first, the controls suck something fierce, but after you play for a while you will start to get used to them and they won't be a problem anymore, although how you run and how you use a weapon is still dumb. And of course one really fun thing about the newer games is that they have really cool kill animations. Here they are pretty crappy. One really great thing about this game (for me at least) is despite its age, there were no compatibility issues (Win 8.1 Pro) and no sound/control/mouse sensitivity issues which you will see in a lot of PC games that are as old as this one.If you can afford Conviction and/or Blacklist, buy those over this for sure. If you like those games and want more Splinter Cell, then this is where you wanna go next.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												I was always a big hardcore fan of the Splinter Cell Series. To this day, I still lowkey enjoy the games whenever I feel like binging on a "James Bond" induced spy thriller. This is the passion that I felt like when playing this game at first. Sneaking through enemy guards through crevasses and navigating in the dark. It really does give the player a unique spy experience. But, however it falls off in a lot of categories which really doesn't match up to modern day expectations. And, you can't really blame the game just because it's a little outdated by at least a decade.First of all, the most recognizable control problem when going into the game for the first time is the SNEAKING. It's kinda hard to figure out at first but, you have to scroll with your mouse to control the intensity of the sneak. and whenever you f*ck up just because you forgot to sneak softer totally blows and you have to start back from save. (not even auto save, so yeap you gotta remember to save). The sneaking controls are more preferably for the console controller due to the analog stick requirement of ease for lockpicking and sneaking. Another problem is the level design. Pretty much it's linear. Point A to Point B, while also filling out objectives.This one sometimes get's on my nerves, but sometimes you just start calling the guards f*ken blind for not spotting you like 2 meters away. Like, I know it's a game and stuff, but it should at least simulate realism.A good aspect I liked was the storytelling, always loved it, and Fisher's comments are pretty hilarious at times.Overall, in the end you either finish the game by looking for a walkthrough of the game because it get's very hard to locate objectives some times. OR, you just rage quit and save time.Good shoppings customer!

number of helpful: 5 of 18 people (28%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												"Damn it Fisher". The only good Splinter Cell game. Or at least the only one that's memorable or some what worthwhile. Chaos Theroy is both over rated and severly dated (Coming from someone who grew up with far older titles I think that says something) and if your wondering if you should buy the game you might notice that all the positive reviews say it's great without explaining why. The story is a Call of Duty esque snore and the stealth is simplistic and boring but I must reluctantly say since there's a lot of freedom in how you deal with enemies (Kill or do not kill) or for how you can screw up it's still a video game (Take that for what you will).The AI springs between aimbot accuracy, sloth like, and just plain blind and or stupid. Unlike the console versions you can actually see whats going on as the PS2 and original Xbox version suffer from pitch blackness gamma syndrome even with the goggles or turning up your TV's brightness settings all the way. The graphics get the job done in regards to the world but the character models are frankly attrocious and suffer from pre next gen Ubisoft graphics with the enemy models looking especially bad (Barely better than Max Payne's) what with their mouths being green. The character models and blurry badly animated CGI make the game look even older than most PS2 games. Hell for 2005 it wasn't even the best stealth game. I think that title goes to Metal Gear Solid 3: Subsistance which was the re release of the 2004 original on weaker hardware that added a free thirdperson camera which is embarrassing considering that this Splinter Cell has better hardware than MGS 3 to work with on the Gamecube and Xbox Original and of course the PC.The real issue is it's terrible controls and awkward bindings for mouse and keyboard. The console controls were already wonky (And thats coming from someone who's used tank controls, pressure sensitive controls and motion controls.) but here on the PC both options control as if you were drunk. It's controls are harder to understand and get a grip on than any of the Arma titles and yes that extends to Operation Flashpoint/Cold War Assault. You name it and it will probably control better than Chaos Theroy (Middle mouse to aim, shft to jump?). At least you can rebind some of the conrols (The mouse wheel effecting your speed is interesting albiet flawed). If your excuse is "bad controls incentivise sneaking or avoiding combat" than every stealth game prior or afterwards would like to have a word with you.It's a mediocre third person shooter disguised as a stealth game with that aspect only just barely being above average and with the latter being primarily in focus. It's voice acting, music, level design, COOP and lack of Uplay are the only thing that salvages it from being total♥♥♥♥♥♥in my eyes. Even then the COOP is capped at 35 FPS for some bizarre reason and its hard to even get it working. If you like scanning crates and bad spanish accents this is the game for you. If you like stealth try anything else (Might I suggest Hitman: Blood Money or Theif?).I don't usually do numbered score but I give Splinter Cell: Chaos Theroy a 3/5 or a 4 out of 10.

												Entertaining dialogue and cool goggles.However since there are no checkpoints, and grabbing enemies from behind is often unresponsive (especially if they are sitting in a chair) - it leads to frequent save scumming.How dark some of the shadows are is visually inconsistent sometimes, and enemies occasionally instantly whipping around 180 in their paths doesn't help either.Even when everything is going according to plan, the sneaking really isn't that entertaining. content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
Cheers- Runs great (on a laptop that struggles with most games post-2003)- Impressive lighting/shadow/textures (see above)- Snappy controls (much, much better than Pandora Tomorrow on Gamecube)- Tactical lightbulb-shooting actionJeers- Some lightbulbs are invincible?- Fairly linear (not always a con, but definitely with stealth)- Repetitive enemy encounters (follow and grab, follow and grab)- Unnecessary gameplay clutter (why do I get hundreds of rounds of ammo, sticky shocker doodads, cameras, grenades, and twelve variations on Google Glass when just a knife would suffice?)- How do any of these generic baddies even perform normal human functions in workplaces so dimly lit? They haven't got a chance!NotesChaos Theory stands head and shoulders above Pandora Tomorrow on Gamecube--the only other Splinter Cell I've played--but that doesn't necessarily mean it's an enjoyable game.The stealth is tight, the controls are great, and the graphics are unusually impressive. But the fun is somehow lacking. Performing takedown after takedown, quicksaving after every one, and rarely, if ever, using a weapon of any kind is the M.O. here, and that just doesn't equate to a fulfilling experience. Even the temporary thrill of stalking a baddie into a corner and performing a surprise jugular-ectomy is dampened by the thought that twenty more of those experiences await you further on in the level.I guess what I'm saying is--it's not a game for me. I bought it in a bundle, so I'm not too bummed. I just wish there was a spark of life in Chaos Theory, some real zest... Some pizzazz.Nope. (Stalk stalk stalk, slash slash slash.)

Posted: March 9
												Best Splinter Cell ever.Freedom to take on the objectives the way you prefer. Want to get in guns blazing? Do it! (Not the best strategy though), want to play as a shadow? Go ahead!, you want a more balanced playstyle? We got you covered.I like the mission ratings, secondary and optional objectives pop up during the missions and help you increase your mission score. (Pro tip: Killing people hurts the mission performance).Conspiracies arise during the story of the game, and secondary characters from past installments become central to the plot in this game. The variety of enviroments where the missions take place is incredible. We'll be visiting South America, NYC and Japan, infiltrating buildings, offices, military bases, cargo vessels and more.Something that nearly screwed up my experience was the fact that thermal vision wasn't working properly with my newest drivers. Had to look for a fix on the internet.I wish there was people to play the co-op missions with, I enjoyed them back in the day while playing this game on the original Xbox.

Posted: August 10, 2013
												For only $9.99, you can play one of the best games in the series. I was a bit skeptical at first after playing Double Agent, which is my favorite so far, but this game was definitely worth my time and money. The gameplay was similar enough to older games that  vetrans could pick it up and breeze right through it, while new players to the series will be able to learn as they go. It added some new mechanics, like the aural bar to minitor Sam's noise level and compares it to the noise level around him, more realistic AI detection, and the close qaurters combat was greatly improved. The levels are not completely linear, as you can choose different routes to complete different objectives, but they are linear enough to avoid backtracking. If you are looking for an action/stealth game, this is the best you can get for $10.

Posted: February 5, 2014
												One of the best (if not the best) stealth games ever madeThis is it. If you want the most in-depth Splinter Cell experience offering everything the stealth genre has to offer and more, look no further. Chaos Theory is Splinter Cell at its prime, taking the stealth genre to new heights with all of its features.As Sam Fischer, you must navigate your way through enemy territory to uncover plans, eliminate targets, and do all you can to put a stop to a diabolical terrorist plan that could mean World War 3 if the villains succeed. Story-wise, this is about what you would expect from a Splinter Cell game and it can be pretty intriguing to say the least. The single player is a decent length, featuring 10 levels at high security areas that for me took roughly 13+ hours to complete.Let's get this out of the way. The game was released in 2005, so of course the visuals are dated. The characters' eyes are kind of big and googly, backgrounds can look very bland, etc. But if you can look at and appreciate the textures and details for what they were at the time, you will overlook the graphics and concentrate on what really matters (and this can be said about many old games). The dialogue is thrilling Tom Clancy as usual. You receive orders from Lambert as usual as well as chatter from your other Third Echelon members. What really shines here are the many, many jokes, sarcastic remarks, and gripping words Sam uses in various instances. Not only does he retort with witty responses over the radio back to Lambert as he did in SC1 and Pandora Tomorrow, but also during the vast amount of interrogations he has with enemies should you choose to put the choke hold on them. I really got a kick out of Sam's exchanges with foes in his grasp; enemy: "What's going on?" Sam: "Are you supposed to be here? Identify yourself" or "I'm the landlord and Zerkhezi forgot to pay his rent. Any idea where he is?" Just like the stealth options, these responses seem limitless and different for each enemy that I interrogated (and there are many basic enemies you can interrogate in each of the 10 levels).Here is what truly makes this game soar: the GAMEPLAY! Game developers could learn (or relearn, as some seem to have forgotten) several concepts of how to approach an action-packed spy tale while getting rid of the cliches and mundane, run-of-the-mill gameplay mechanics of today (Assassin Creed's "kill guy from hay bale, leap out, run to next instant kill point, repeat" comes to mind here). Chaos Theory gives the player a multitude of options: Open door? Open door stealthily? Bash door open? Pick lock? Break lock? Optic cable? Many doors have all of these options for whatever you are feeling at the time. DIstracting guards: Pick up and throw object? Whistle? Blast light with EMP from pistol? Or take the old way and just shoot out the light? There are also several routes to the objective(s) and you can spend several playthroughs going through the level, perhaps through the vents here and taking out the guard there or maybe climbing up the pole and onto the balcony this time to snag the intel and avoid the first floor cameras. The point is that the choices are so many and you are constantly hammered with scenarios in which you can do it all again and again. It is all up to you and how you want to play the game. This type of game most likely inspired the varied choices of stealth games like Dishonored and Mark of the Ninja because it plays much the same way. It's perfect!One minor flaw is that the AI can be sort of annoying in some areas, especially the Seoul level later on when the fighting breaks out. It can be difficult to maneuver around these guys which, at the drop of a hat, can instantly recognize you and fire upon you before you even know you were spotted. However this is typically not the case, as most of the game takes place in areas with relative amounts of darkness to use to sneak by the unsuspecting guards.All in all, this was a wonderful gaming experience and perfect for any Splinter Cell fan as well as gamers that enjoy true stealth (not the stripped-down stealth games we seem to be having today). 9.5/10

Posted: December 31, 2013
												[9/10]Splinter Cell Chaos Theory is a stealth-action game taking place after the previous game, Splinter Cell Pandora Tomorrow (which is not on Steam, sadly). This is the best game in the Splinter Cell franchise, and the best stealth game in general, in my opinion. One of my favorite things about this game is the fact that there are multiple ways to go about getting past a certain obstacle. Plenty of gadgets, the ability to whistle at enemies, tampering with the lights, sneaking up behind enemies and forcing information out of them--all of this is the definition of an amazingly crafted stealth game. Also, being able to go through the game not killing anyone is an option. The story on the other hand is not amazing, but still enough to keep you interested in what's goin on. This game is fantastic, and anyone looking for a stealth focused experience should definitely buy this game.

Posted: August 3, 2014
												This game is absolutely outstanding. I have the first 5 entries of the Splinter Cell franchise on PC, and it really does go to show that Chaos Theory was the evolutionary peak of the franchise. The gameplay mechanics are refined, and the game just plays smoother than Splinter Cell and Pandora Tomorrow. The game also allows you to choose your playstyle, be it super-sneaky, or going in guns blazing, and you can choose your loadout before the mission accordingly. The coop mode is solid too. Unfortunately, there's no one playing the versus Spy Vs Mercs mode anymore, so that's a wasted game mode at this time. Another issue myself, and other people have had is the fact that the in-game Steam overlay doesn't appear at all. The only way to fix this is to re-add the game as a non-Steam shortcut. This is annoying as some people would like to take screenshots and whatnot, and as I play on a laptop, would like to see a battery warning pop up when I'm not charging. But all in all, this is a brilliant game that stills looks brillliant despite the fact that it's something like 9 years old. If you found the restrictions in Pandora Tomorrow frustratating (such as one little mistake and you've triggered an alarm), then this is what you need- it's easier to get around mistakes... but it's not an easy game on its hardest difficulty.

Posted: February 2, 2014
												Last part of the classic Splinter Cell series. Any "Splinter Cell" game after the original 3, is by name only and not canon.+ A through and through stealth game, filled with lots of "TECHNOLOGY!" moments. For example, Sam breathing a sigh of relief after having a close encounter with a guard, but remaining undectected. Shifting his body to try and avoid coming into contact with a passing guard, while putting his hand near his knife or gun just incase♥♥♥♥♥♥hits the fan. Audio queues like Sam muttering "C'mon", or "Gimmie a break" while he's lock picking or a simple "oops" when tripping a laser grid. These are things we take for granted nowadays in video games, but back in 2005 this was almost revolutionary for the hardware Chaos Theory was running on.+ Sam is on point with his witty and dry sense of humor which never fails to make me chuckle. Sams support team characters are really well written and play off each other well. Especially Sam and Grimm, lots of Grimm calling Sam old and other running jokes that follow inbetween missions. Sam isn't just a ruthless wet worker, like he is portrayed in later games (again not canon) he has a moral compass and you're given the opition to follow it at certain points in the game, which is cool feature.+ Guards will react to changes in their environment. For example if you switch a light off in a guards patrol route, on his way back around he'll notice it and go turn it back on. Same for candles, if you blow it out they'll go and relight it. They react to broken lights by pulling out a flashlight or a flare. They remember if they shut the door they came through, so if you leave a door open while you're sneaking about and a guard remembers that it was originally closed, he'll come and investigate it. Again not really very revolutionary, but it's still a really cool feature and helps the guards feel less robotic.- Product placement, subtle product placement sure, but it's still there. Ads on computer screensavers for Nokia phones, billboards for Axe (Lynx in the UK) deoderant, Airwaves gum at one point too I think. I hate that sorta crap.- Guards will sometimes just randomly spot you despite the fact you are completely consealed. Or the ever famous stealth game staple the "psychic 180" where you are meeting all the right parameters to sneak up on a guard, but he just magiacally knows you're there, spins right around and guns you down. Frustrating.- Some character models have a visible line right down their model from top of their head to their grion. Some facial textures distort when you have hold of a guard. And sometimes when you can see Sams eyes he is almost always♥♥♥♥♥♥eyed, which while hilarious is majorly immersion breaking sometimes. Someone somewhere in the modeling and texture team ♥♥♥♥ed up big.- Doesn't support Steam overlay, so if someone messages you then you will need to tab out of the game to reply.- Not much of an ending. It just sorta trails off... And the story feels a bit out of whack sometimes.- - The multiplayer isn't brought up to spec like the single player is. It runs terribly and doesn't support up-to-date resolutions. Shame really, since Chaos Theory Spies vs Mercs was really good.All in all, it's still a great game, and one of my favorite stealth games of all time. It's a shame Ubisoft♥♥♥♥♥♥all over the series with Double Agent, Conviciton and Blacklist. They're not Splinter Cell games. They're action shoot 'em ups with the Splinter Cell name slapped on.

Posted: June 24, 2016
												One of the best stealth games ever made, as well as the best and the last good Splinter Cell game. Highlights include:-multiple ways to navigate the levels and accomplish objectives, ranging from equipment selection to the paths you can take. There is a true freedom of choice, even when you find yourself in a forced encounter later in the game.-high character interactivity: Fisher can walk or crouch walk at different speeds, vault over walls, climb pipes, balance himself between 2 walls, enter airducts, pick up and throw objects, roll, jump, whistle, hack electronics from a distance, use weapons ambidextrously, cut through tent walls, and more. Most of the things you can imagine doing in the situations you find yourself in, you can.-the shadows still look great today, and there are environmental effects like clothing getting wet when exposed to rain. Most modern games today don't have these.-realistic interactions with the environment: water conducts electricity, unconscious people die if they're dropped from too high, knocking someone unconscious on water and not carrying him off will cause him to drown, carrying bodies around is taxing for Fisher and slows him down, etc. You feel like you're in a realistic world controlling a person that has physical limits.-amazing and cool soundtrack that stays varied through the entire game-robust stealth: enemies are fairly smart and don't have memories that expire in 2 seconds (and doing stupid things like whistling when near them will immediately get them to shooting), stages have many surveillance devices or traps, alarms make enemies more resilient and paranoid, environmental sound and light are always deciding factors for the approach you have to take, your equipment provides help in so many different ways (such as using sticky cameras to scout ahead and even distract guards)-point system that encourages perfectionist players to play the game with no kills and no detections as it is really supposed to be played, as well as no-kill restrictions on some levels-great dialogue and banter between Fisher and the other characters paint an interesting and multi-dimensional picture of him as a character. These were not the days when everybody were edgy and angry killing machines; Fisher jokes around with friends and enemies but also shows concern and anger at times, such as when ordered by Lambert to leave plane-wrecked pilots in a site that is soon to be bombed, and even makes political commentary. Grimsdottir is not an action girl but a computer nerd that jokes about her grade school days. Many enemies have their own unique interrogation dialogues (and these were actual interrogations brought on by a display of force, not torture as in Conviction) and quite a few are portrayed sympathetically.-interesting and fairly complex story that doesn't work in its entirety, but is pretty good otherwise. Also notes to discover and read that reveal small details about the present events in the game's timeline.-co-op and multiplayer modes that feel completely different from the singleplayer experience. The co-op mode is not just great fun, its storyline also intersects with the singleplayer's. The multiplayer puts heavily armed mercenaries that see the world in first person versus lightly armed but agile and resourceful Splinter Cell-like spies that have a third person camera.-no regenerating health but limited numbers of health pickups scattered around. In the hardest difficulty detection is frequently synonymous with death.A must play for anyone interested in the stealth genre, as well as a timeless reminder taht Ubisoft used to be able to make great games.

Posted: July 27, 2015
												Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory. Where do I begin?For a game released in 2004, the graphics are simply fantastic. That's all that needs to be said.The gameplay is, even by today's standards, in a league of its own. I love how the player is able to affect the course of the story in-game with simple, nifty features such as plenty of NPCs being able to give synopsises of the plot when you grab and interrogate them. Or how about at the beginning of every chapter when the game allows you to choose your load out: stealth for more non-lethal weapons such as the infamous sticky cams, choosing assault gives you heaps of ammo, but fewer non-lethal gizmos, but Redding's reccomendation gives you an even mix of both.There is a lot of puzzle solving to be done, such as in a certain chapter when you have to use a captured enemy's "electric shadow" (very Sci-Fi) in order to pass through a laser-beam grid without triggering the alarms. I struggle to think of any bad things about this game... Oh no, I have found one! It's too short! I was expecting the game to be at least three chapters longer than it is. But still, too much of something is too good... or bad... whatever.Definitely reccomend this game to fans of stealth as this was one of the defining games of the defining franchise of stealth gaming. It's a real pity that the future Splinter Cells just simply weren't as good as the first three games, this being the third.i r8 420/69 wud watch otomo seppuku again.

As for conviction, it made Sam look like a brutal assassin, which he is. But, In conviction, the game was too easy and repeatative. Chaos Theory on the other hand, has a something that both games don't have. Splinter Cell Chaos Theory is simply a great balance of Sam's abilities ; sam isn't too weak, and Sam isn't to strong. If you've played the 1st Splinter Cell and had a bad experience with it, play this game! It is alot better. It fixes alot of the annoying game mechanics from the 1st. 												Don't let the little playtime fool you. I logged many hours on the xbox version. It was because of the many great memories I had that I decided to purchase this on steam. The single player is fun. Especially messing around with the guards. "Somebody turned out the light!" Everyone who knows what I'm talking about just said that in their head using that one guy's voice. LOL it doesn't get any better than that. The multiplayer is where this game shines but the servers have been shut down. You won't be able to play unless you use another service like hamachi or tungle. I used tungle and found a few other players. We were able to get a decent 2v2 game going and had a blast. The controls aren't as fluid as the xbox version. It can be jarring when you run into the merc and only want to get away but fail because of this. If you see this game pick it up. It absolutely revolutionized the multiplayer scene when it came out. In my opinion it still holds up to many modern day games even if the graphics are a little outdated.

Posted: January 30, 2014
												  I... I just can't. This is the epitome of stealth games. Any other game, whether a different franchise, or even sequels with better graphics, can't hold a candle to Chaos Theory. It has the most realistic feel of any action/thriller game I've ever played. You are given minimal help throughout the mission. There are certain moments in games when you get lost, have no idea what you're doing, etc. Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory is the embodiment of that feeling. This game is legendary. Also, the graphics are not half bad. I can run maximum settings with my Inspiron 660 with an AMD Radeon 7770.   The AI's are pretty phenomenal. It's hard not to get immersed in the world of Chaos Theory right off the bat. I once chose to spare a guard because he was talking about what a pathetic paycheck he gets, and how he'll never be able to afford motion sensor lights. It's very impressive how well this game can both absorb you and excite you--all with minimal blood and gore.   This is a game about making decisions, critical thinking, and strategy. Approaching a guard silently from behind, hoping he won't turn around, moments like that make your heart explode. It's amazing how well the game makes you absorb that true stealth badass identity. You can feel yourself in Fisher's every movement. The way he draws his knife as approaching an enemy, his clever interrogation dialogue; all of these contribute to his hard-core character.  SC:CT will not dissapoint. Some might take one glance at it and say, "Oh, 2005. Not for me." This is one of my favorite games, and just keeps climbing up the list. Dry, self-aware wit, stellar lighting, and interesting plot make Chaos Theory what it is today. $10 for a legend.

												What an enthralling, tense, cool and expertly polished experience this was. Grand level designs with lots and lots of ways for interaction enaged me on a level where my attention was catapulted to extreme heights. You can even (kinda) rambo it too! It's a welcome change after the laser stealth focus of the previous two and unlike the new one none of the stealth goodness is lost if you choose to be a whisper. Optional objectives help flesh out the gameplay. But, God, it's the music that holds everything in place. Genre bending, superbly composed and eminently listenable by the Great Amon Tobin, it matches the dark, slick, uber cool mood of the game. Easily one of the greatest Game ost's ever. Utube it for chrissakes!! The cherry on top is made up of GFX. Made using a modified UE 2.5 the game has some great looking levels and shadowing. Gorgeous even 7 years on, with stellar lighting. Buy this, at sale, full price or gift it.A fine, fine, fine game.

Posted: December 5, 2014
												The definitive Splinter Cell game: Chaos Theory ironed out the imperfections present in Splinter Cell and Pandora Tomorrow, whilst also retaining what was good about the first two, to achieve perfection as, not just an entry in the Splinter Cell series but, as stealth-based games go.While I enjoyed the first Splinter Cell’s storyline, Nikoladze and the Georgian information crisis, I thought Pandora Tomorrow’s (East Timorese rebels) was somewhat lacking. Chaos Theory returns to form though as Sam Fisher must prevent full-scale war erupting on the Korean Peninsula.Chaos Theory was the point where the series matured and achieved perfection. Michael Ironside must have had a blast recording Sam Fisher’s dialogue for this edition. There are nuggets of pure comedy gold among Sam’s dialogue, such as when he cons a National Guardsman into believing his presence (and knife at his throat) is simply a training exercise, or Grimsdottir’s most recent attempt to set him up on a date.Aside from the introduction of a knife and the OCP on the pistol there are no new weapons in Sam’s arsenal but there are a number of new non-lethal ways of dealing with your enemies. The OCP is a huge boon, used to temporarily disable electric lighting which not just saves bullets but also helps maintain your stealth as the AI’s powers of perception have improved greatly, especially when spotting broken lights. Sam can also change what arm his SC-20K is resting on, making shooting around left-sided corners without being detected much easier. The ability to choose the contents of your weaponry prior to starting a mission (recommendation, stealth, or assault) is another cool introduction. Players are also marked on their performance at the end of each mission out of 100%, with non-lethal kills, never being detected as an intruder, and the completion of secondary objectives contributing to your final score.As well as feeling much more authentic than its two predecessors in terms of graphics and lighting, Chaos Theory also saw the first time Sam had a relationship with one of the antagonists, which culminates in a gripping showdown reminiscent of GoldenEye. Overall the dialogue is snappier, the gameplay more fluid, the graphics sharper, which unsurprisingly makes it just as enjoyable to play as it was back in 2005.A massive 10/10: the best entry of the whole Splinter Cell series.

												The Splinter Cell series has always had a special place in my heart and soul. Chaos Theory is the most significant fragment within that series - no competitors (but Blacklist does come rather close).If you are new to the series, or you'd like to try out the games, then Chaos Theory is the place to start. It is the prime example of a game done right, and I highly recommend you give it a try.Things you will love about it:- funny accents - smooth gameplay- great story- great soundtrack- great map design- the multiplayer was great back then, so bring in a friend for CoOp- flexibility in play styles- loadout selections (this was the first time for Splinter Cell games)- even more funny accents- etc.
