Posted: November 19, 2010
												The greatest Splinter Cell I have ever played and quite frankly, I will EVER play. A solid and meaty singleplayer campaign puts you in the shoes of Sam Fisher, an elite covert 'spy' who works for the NSA's "Third Echelon" organisation. A series of events that start from a simple kidnapping to the near outbreak of World War III puts you right in the action and uncover the truth behind the lies of governments, the schemes of war and cyber terrorism in this brilliant and well made steath game. A game of patience and skill or a round of sheer run and gun madness, you can play Splinter Cell how you want and the fifth freedom is yours to fiddle with. The co-op/VS mode is brilliant, bring a friend along and have double the stealth and action! This game is the best that Ubisoft have made for the Splinter Cell series to this date. Not to mention the hilarious interrogations and sheer brilliance of actor Michael Ironside's voice for Sam Fisher. Buy this game, you'll love it!

Posted: March 6, 2016
												I played this on the ps2 a year or so after it was released. It was my first Splinter Cell title. I spent months only playing up until finding the man in the first mission, until I realized there was a door to load the next section. Once I got past that, it opened the door to loving Splinter Cell, and other stealth genre games.I've heard plenty say this is the center piece of the series, and I somewhat agree. Of course it would be best to start at the first one, but playing this certainly gave a wonderful feel for the rest, Pre-Conviction. -Graphically, it was great for its time of 2006 I believe, and to this day, I still marvel at some of the maps, and the atmosphere they can put off. It of course looks dated by today's standards, but it doesn't bother me much, which makes sense given the impact in my gaming life it had. I liked it still, and for those who don't mind older looks, this is certainly something then, but as I said, some spots still look quite good for today.-Gameplay/mechanics wise, I also enjoyed it. Mostly. You actually had a JUMP button. You got to experiment with what you can climb on. If you can make that jump and grab hold. Your only shimmy technique was hands only and no legs, but it was still fine for what it was. Climbing over objects felt right. A little jump, bracing your feet, then vaulting over that railway. It felt so good, as did doing that then dragging a guy over the edge.    ~Guards were, a bit dumb in some places. But still pretty good. They remembered stuff... they were made to notice things. Lights off, doors opened, locks broken, or dead bodies in a chair. You know. simple things. Being able to hide in a dark corner inches from them as they occasionally clip through you was ridiculous however, but that's permitted I'd think. No stealth game has perfected itself, especially not a decade ago.    ~Combat was interesting. Each game does it different, but in this, it was before regeneration, and where the game really meant for you to not be a panther and wreck everyone. Doesn't mean I never tried, but it's rewarding when you played like the silent ghost you were meant to be. shooting could end you in seconds, forcing you to ensure you knew what you were planning. A draw back of decade old game is you can't shoot that guy, knife another, then grab the third in a span of two seconds like you can now. Fisher is totally capable of doing it in this, but it just wasn't able to be done, or wasn't thought to be implemented yet. Dunno.   ~Sneaking was actually necessary. It's what gave you the ability to hear that extra dialog, whether it be for a secondary objective, or for a funny. It was also just.. necessary. It is a damn stealth game after all. Not saying running around with a shotgun, ragdolling people wasn't fun when bored. But, it was nice to take your time, look for that extra path, get that silent interrogation. Or, not touch a single person, and evesdrop. ( Touching someone lowers your score, yo. )  -The plot wasn't anything special, but it was just fine for this little family of people. Good guy go finds thing, discovers news about another thing, goes to find thing, travels to other places about thing, finds out info about guy involving thing, Good Guy looks and finds guy involved with bad thing, emotional moment ensues, and you press on to save the day in a climatic ending. After navigating an annoying as sh*t base. Only finished that last mission once. It's been a while. for the average player, it isn't something new. but for avid lovers of the franchise, it means the world. -The characters. Oh, the characters. We have the smooth, bald, head rubbing leader Lambert. We have the computer wiz Grimsdottir. We have our tech man Reading. And a few others along the way that give you a briefing. Charming U.S. captain, an old friend or two, and a few other folk I can't recall, along with a whole set of guards and civilians you come across in each mission. Then we have Fisher, pride and true man of Third Echelon. The man you play as. The best of the best. And a great interrogater, with a big knife, and sharp humor. Words are exchangable. Lambert, Reeding, and Grim are with you always through voice comunication. And the group that you grow to love from 1 to double agent. They all have plenty of bits of humor too. This is meant to be a serious game, but every mission, there is at least a couple lines of quick humor, jabs at each other, along with other things you'd hear along the way. Not a day goes by where I don't get giddy hearing dialog bits from Sam, to random baddies in the mission, or to your team. It is certainly something to look forward to cherishing. One of the bigger reasons why I like questioning everyone in new areas, is to find these little nuggets of gold humor. Oh, and did I mention Spy Blue and Spy Red? Cooperative Splinter Cells for the win!-I really don't think this will come to a close naturally, so I'll end it by force. I could go on and on, describing things, telling you all what I loved and .. not so much loved about this game. But honestly I think I've strayed from 'review' enough. It has it's quirks, like bad jumps and loud landings that make no sense, and loud search music from delayed take downs, but it has so much more great moments of comedy, gameplay and just overall enjoyment rolling around and ( optionally) stabbing folk in the back. -As a nostalgic Chaos Theory player, I fully give this a 10/10.-As a somewhat objective person, I give this an 8/10.-As someone with too many bad jokes and a skill of wasting time, I give this an 11/10, and would certainly play again. Have been for 10 years now or so. Grab a friend, do the coop. ( I suggest a video guide for #1, I even couldn't get it. ) Grab yourself... ( hey, not like that ) and play the single player. Do normal, cherish it. Do secondary tasks, or don't. up to you.  I still haven't on every one. But, definitely try to have fun. Or, go hard mode and just wreck yourself. up to you. then invest in every other game and play for hours.  Have fun now.

It's a classic story of espionage and irratible governments, and its up to YOU to figure out the TRUTH... with murder. The options to go through levels is challenging and varies. I'd say good for ages 9 and up, as long as you're ok with them murdering in a virtual world (or witnessing torture*). Certain visions and weapons were banned from use, otherwise the mercs will win within a matter of seconds. The way we played, it was scary for the Mercs as they tried to say alive and kill the spies, the spies just trying to find and make opportunities to take down the mercs. Posted: March 6, 2016
												I played this on the ps2 a year or so after it was released. It was my first Splinter Cell title. I spent months only playing up until finding the man in the first mission, until I realized there was a door to load the next section. Once I got past that, it opened the door to loving Splinter Cell, and other stealth genre games.I've heard plenty say this is the center piece of the series, and I somewhat agree. Of course it would be best to start at the first one, but playing this certainly gave a wonderful feel for the rest, Pre-Conviction. -Graphically, it was great for its time of 2006 I believe, and to this day, I still marvel at some of the maps, and the atmosphere they can put off. It of course looks dated by today's standards, but it doesn't bother me much, which makes sense given the impact in my gaming life it had. I liked it still, and for those who don't mind older looks, this is certainly something then, but as I said, some spots still look quite good for today.-Gameplay/mechanics wise, I also enjoyed it. Mostly. You actually had a JUMP button. You got to experiment with what you can climb on. If you can make that jump and grab hold. Your only shimmy technique was hands only and no legs, but it was still fine for what it was. Climbing over objects felt right. A little jump, bracing your feet, then vaulting over that railway. It felt so good, as did doing that then dragging a guy over the edge.    ~Guards were, a bit dumb in some places. But still pretty good. They remembered stuff... they were made to notice things. Lights off, doors opened, locks broken, or dead bodies in a chair. You know. simple things. Being able to hide in a dark corner inches from them as they occasionally clip through you was ridiculous however, but that's permitted I'd think. No stealth game has perfected itself, especially not a decade ago.    ~Combat was interesting. Each game does it different, but in this, it was before regeneration, and where the game really meant for you to not be a panther and wreck everyone. Doesn't mean I never tried, but it's rewarding when you played like the silent ghost you were meant to be. shooting could end you in seconds, forcing you to ensure you knew what you were planning. A draw back of decade old game is you can't shoot that guy, knife another, then grab the third in a span of two seconds like you can now. Fisher is totally capable of doing it in this, but it just wasn't able to be done, or wasn't thought to be implemented yet. Dunno.   ~Sneaking was actually necessary. It's what gave you the ability to hear that extra dialog, whether it be for a secondary objective, or for a funny. It was also just.. necessary. It is a damn stealth game after all. Not saying running around with a shotgun, ragdolling people wasn't fun when bored. But, it was nice to take your time, look for that extra path, get that silent interrogation. Or, not touch a single person, and evesdrop. ( Touching someone lowers your score, yo. )  -The plot wasn't anything special, but it was just fine for this little family of people. Good guy go finds thing, discovers news about another thing, goes to find thing, travels to other places about thing, finds out info about guy involving thing, Good Guy looks and finds guy involved with bad thing, emotional moment ensues, and you press on to save the day in a climatic ending. After navigating an annoying as sh*t base. Only finished that last mission once. It's been a while. for the average player, it isn't something new. but for avid lovers of the franchise, it means the world. -The characters. Oh, the characters. We have the smooth, bald, head rubbing leader Lambert. We have the computer wiz Grimsdottir. We have our tech man Reading. And a few others along the way that give you a briefing. Charming U.S. captain, an old friend or two, and a few other folk I can't recall, along with a whole set of guards and civilians you come across in each mission. Then we have Fisher, pride and true man of Third Echelon. The man you play as. The best of the best. And a great interrogater, with a big knife, and sharp humor. Words are exchangable. Lambert, Reeding, and Grim are with you always through voice comunication. And the group that you grow to love from 1 to double agent. They all have plenty of bits of humor too. This is meant to be a serious game, but every mission, there is at least a couple lines of quick humor, jabs at each other, along with other things you'd hear along the way. Not a day goes by where I don't get giddy hearing dialog bits from Sam, to random baddies in the mission, or to your team. It is certainly something to look forward to cherishing. One of the bigger reasons why I like questioning everyone in new areas, is to find these little nuggets of gold humor. Oh, and did I mention Spy Blue and Spy Red? Cooperative Splinter Cells for the win!-I really don't think this will come to a close naturally, so I'll end it by force. I could go on and on, describing things, telling you all what I loved and .. not so much loved about this game. But honestly I think I've strayed from 'review' enough. It has it's quirks, like bad jumps and loud landings that make no sense, and loud search music from delayed take downs, but it has so much more great moments of comedy, gameplay and just overall enjoyment rolling around and ( optionally) stabbing folk in the back. -As a nostalgic Chaos Theory player, I fully give this a 10/10.-As a somewhat objective person, I give this an 8/10.-As someone with too many bad jokes and a skill of wasting time, I give this an 11/10, and would certainly play again. Have been for 10 years now or so. Grab a friend, do the coop. ( I suggest a video guide for #1, I even couldn't get it. ) Grab yourself... ( hey, not like that ) and play the single player. Do normal, cherish it. Do secondary tasks, or don't. up to you.  I still haven't on every one. But, definitely try to have fun. Or, go hard mode and just wreck yourself. up to you. then invest in every other game and play for hours.  Have fun now.

Posted: August 2, 2014
												Stealth is all about patience. And this game is one big test of your tactical skills and patience. In my opinion, the best in the series, and in the genre, Splinter Cell Chaos Theory towers over all stealth games, the only other game that managed to get near the perfection of this game was indie hit, Mark of The Ninja, but let's talk about Chaos Theory. Sam Fisher, a splinter cell agent, a one man special ops agent, is tasked by the his agency to find the missing agent on an island, he finds him, and the whole web of conspiracies and plans to start a new world war uncover. The story is excellent, about informational warfare, thin line between war and peace, and the extent a man must go to prevent something sinister. Story is really good, like a good spy-thriller movie.  Gameplay is upgraded from the previous games, more complex, but in the same time, more rewarding. Your main thought that should guide you throughout the game is "SNEAK". You will die of one shot, so think and be patient. There's a new lighting system in the game, showing you, out of 4 levels of lighting, whether enemy can see you or not. A sound system shows the sound you're making by walking, and the sound of the ambient (TVs, radios...), this allows you to walk faster, or shoot the guy, not risking getting caught. Graphics are beautiful, especially seen in the boat mission, the lighting effects on the old walls of boat really gives you the emersion you need.All in all, stealth fans, get this. It is an old game, but it is a game that passed the test of time, and is one of the more complex and best stealth games out there. A must have.

Posted: August 14, 2016
												Finally, after two games, the Splinter Cell series has reached its potential and delivered in Chaos Theory an exciting spy adventure. Only it's a Clancy-esque affair, so expect more military-technology jargon and less Sam Fisher taking his jumpsuit offer to impress a roster of Russian ladies. The story is rather standard for the series. It revolves around World War Three being on the brink of starting once again and its up to Sam Fisher and his covert ways of working to stop it happening. There are linkages to the storyline of the first game, which despite only playing the original game recently, I didn't get as I was too busy battling the oversensitive AI and poor contextualised movement to notice fine details of the plot. Nevertheless, they aren't important to understand and you can enjoy Chaos Theory's story in all its predicatability without having played the predecessors. The gameplay and level design have been improved dramatically this time around, to the point that the game still feels challenging but not unfairly so. Enemies won't spot you in pitch darkness any more, which is great. There's a fantastic sound meter instead, which shows how loud you are. Enemies will know your position just by listening, so watch out! This system makes the far more realistic and tense. And there are now multiple routes in, out and around levels, something that had no reason not to exist from the get go in my opinion. But it's here now and the game's all the better for it. You are now able to choose your loadouts before missions too, but really, I found no real reason to use anything but the Stealth option, even when I chose to engage the enemies (who can easily chop your health bar to zero if you engage more than one at a time). This option always seemed to have enough ammo and gadgetry to last me through any given mission. There is a rating system now, which gives you impetus to replay missions and do the side objectives. These side objectives aren't token either; they expose the conspiracy afoot in the game's story and doing them sooner rather than later allows for less negotiation of armed guards later on to grab the piece of the puzzle. The pistols alternative fire now more subtly disables cameras and there's a hacking minigame now, but it's really pretty shallow once you get used to it. I cannot ignore the fact that, graphically, this game is still a beauty to look at. While textures and fire effects, as well as the cutscenes, are actually quite ugly by today's standards, the lighting, shadows, character movement and sound effects are top notch. There is real depth in both the lighting and sounds in this game, reflected in the brilliant sound and light meters that define the gameplay. If you have to play any of the Splinter Cells (as to stealth fans, I would still recommend any Hitman game or Deus Ex over these), make sure it is Chaos Theory. It's worth the asking price just for the Panama bank level alone.8/10.

The multiplayer is where this game shines but the servers have been shut down. You won't be able to play unless you use another service like hamachi or tungle. In my opinion it still holds up to many modern day games even if the graphics are a little outdated.

Posted: July 27, 2015
												Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory. Where do I begin?For a game released in 2004, the graphics are simply fantastic. That's all that needs to be said.The gameplay is, even by today's standards, in a league of its own. I love how the player is able to affect the course of the story in-game with simple, nifty features such as plenty of NPCs being able to give synopsises of the plot when you grab and interrogate them. Or how about at the beginning of every chapter when the game allows you to choose your load out: stealth for more non-lethal weapons such as the infamous sticky cams, choosing assault gives you heaps of ammo, but fewer non-lethal gizmos, but Redding's reccomendation gives you an even mix of both.There is a lot of puzzle solving to be done, such as in a certain chapter when you have to use a captured enemy's "electric shadow" (very Sci-Fi) in order to pass through a laser-beam grid without triggering the alarms. I struggle to think of any bad things about this game... Oh no, I have found one! It's too short! I was expecting the game to be at least three chapters longer than it is. But still, too much of something is too good... or bad... whatever.Definitely reccomend this game to fans of stealth as this was one of the defining games of the defining franchise of stealth gaming. It's a real pity that the future Splinter Cells just simply weren't as good as the first three games, this being the third.i r8 420/69 wud watch otomo seppuku again.

Posted: July 18, 2012
												This is an older game, but one definitely worth considering if you enjoy interactive co-op missions and stealth. The co-op is a 2-player setup where you go out on missions in enemy bases during the darkest hours (nighttime :3) to act out some kind of plan. It makes you feel like a secret agent - and man is that a good feeling. Technically speaking it was a very advanced game for its time. The graphics still look pretty decent, and the AI would be alerted to sound, and how visible you were based on the envinonments lights. You could disable or shoot out lights, pick locks, slam doors into people (or thin air in some cases,) and hack computer systems. A very solid stealth game both single player and co-op.

Posted: November 26, 2016
												This game is such a classic in its own right, and is considered one of the best stealth games of all time. Chaos Theory utilizes sound and light to the player's advantage and disadvantage. This gives the player to either outsmart the enemy, or completely screw up and be caught in plain sight. Hence the name, "Chaos Theory", as every action taken by the player can either aid them, or completely screw them over. Each level has its own uniqueness and environment type whether it is set on a huge cargo ship, or an urban jungle. While the character models do look outdated, with the faces crossing over into the uncanny valley, the lighting and environments still look nice after all these years. I highly recommend this game for any fans of stealth and action games.
